content.description:
As the OP points out, no one comes here to boulder.  Totally agree.  But it can be a nice compliment to a day of frazzled nerves at the main crags.  Here's a quick diversion before the last uphill slog on the way back to camp.

The problem climbs an attractive left-leaning intrusion.  A good hold teases you from 10' up, but how to reach it?  Pull off the ground statically, float past the "missing" hold, and on to the top.

Obviously some of the world's best climbers have walked by here and someone could have done this before.  On the other hand, it's somewhat hidden and.... no one comes here to boulder.  If you know of an existing name or FA, let me know and I'll update.
content.location: The first main notch, where the hiking trail descends steeply and then begins switchbacking up to the lookout.  In a cluster of boulders 25 yards south of the trail, close to the base of the switchbacks.

content.description:
A little piece of Horse Pens 40 at 8000 ft in California!!!!  Chicken heads, tough traverses, and a sketchy top out!  Sit start the fun traverse around to the north side of the boulder and power over the slopey top out.

If anyone has a different story, name, FA, anything about this boulder please let me know and I'll update my info.  The last thing I want to do is step on anyone's toes.  Thanks.
content.protection: Someone to keep you from falling down the cliff ... Pad couldn't hurt.
content.location: Follow the normal approach to The Needles but instead of breaking off toward the 'needles' keep following the trail up to the Lookout Tower.  Its about halfway up on the south side.
